title: Interesting Trend
body:
Following Shaco being played in EU LCS yesterday, I've already seen 3 threads discussing how Shaco is OP and needs nerf.


Are you guys serious ?? lmfao

I started learning and maining Shaco start the end of season 3 solely because EVERYONE was saying how SHIT Shaco was and I wanted to play Shaco so that winning makes it a lot more satisfying. 

Not a single change had been made to Shaco since I started playing him, and all it took for some people to start whining about him was just one single game played at a professional scene.


Sad Community

Guys Shaco is all early game and if he doesn't snowball he's not really scary late game. Like seriously. He's not hard to ward against because you know where he thinks the ward is going to be (in the bush) so you know where to put the ward (right before the bush where he would have to go invisible at to 'avoid' the ward), pink wards exist, he's super squishy, and he doesn't do a lot of damage if you don't stand in his boxes with your back towards him.

He's a nice jungler if you have a team that you can work with early, but it's not like he's OP.

Playing Shaco is basically "ok I won the lanes and we're ahead now, better close this out quickly... oh look the team is dicking around because they think we've won... now their Swain has 8 kills... team still dicking around... ok I've fallen off now... nexus is dead".

This is why I've never tried to take earlygame junglers into soloq. It's not that much harder to win the jungle with the ones that don't fall off.

I main support so I'm not really the most tower wrecking of champions but I absolutely adore duo partners who focus objectives and want to end games before the 30 minute mark when I duo with an ADC I ward up and try to get us to take the inner turret instead of going straight to midlane. Find duos that are decent players at your elo and will focus towers with you. If 2 of you are doing it you can convince your team to follow

That isn't what happened with Sejuani at all actually, she got a full on micro rework  back in preseason that actually boosted her to a very competitive level (she had a 54% win rate before the Cinderhulk patch and had shown up in *several* pro games across all regions). Cinder hulk boosted her up to a 58% win rate and that in itself isn't what made her OP, it just made people notice that she was already OP.
So true.  Sej had been in a solid spot for some time, it just took her being incredibly OP for people to finally notice her.

You have a point (and just to be clear I absolutely agree with your actual point) but your example of Sejuani is incorrect, previous to cinderhulk she was already strong and being played quite successfully. A better example would be a different tank jungler like Nautilus. Though he may not have been or is now a big ban, he is quite powerful, being played in the lcs and in soloq fairly regularly, in stark contrast to his previously much lower pick rate.

While I agree that even if a champion is unchanged, the game can change around said champ and make them suddenly an appealing pick. 

However, this is just not the case with Shaco. Shaco isn't particularly interested in Cinderhulk, the item that started the jungle buzz in 5.5. He doesn't benefit from the Athene's buff unless for some reason you build him AP, which is dumb unless its an ARAM. Soooo....exactly what game change are you referring to that made Shaco nerf-worthy? If anything the fact that he falls off makes him LESS viable because tank junglers scale extraordinarily well into the late game and Shaco doesn't hardly at all. Rek'Sai is still good, Vi is still good, Lee Sin is good, meaning there are also early game junglers that can prevent Shaco and his lanes from snowballing. All in all, I agree with what you are saying, but Shaco does not need to be nerfed. He is at most a tertiary beneficiary of various changes, and even that is stretching it.

Also, quick note on Sejuani: most people already said Cinderhulk might push her to OP status, and she was already seeing LCS play before Cinderhulk's introduction. So I don't think people thought she was trash-tier at all.

Shaco as a champion is *not* OP. It was the way that UOL was able to punish GMB's faulty engages that allowed UOL to trade safely versus GMB while Shaco was able to push towers. IIRC the announcer specifically said Shaco became a strong factor in the game because he took a **long** amount of time farming the lanes and pushing towers. The extra gold allowed him to build more items at a faster rate. Also, if GMB were able to take care of Shaco and find him in his jungle early on, especially during their invade, Shaco would of been behind the enemy jungler. Going back to my original point, Diamond's error of leaving top lane at the beginning of the game left Cabochard wide open for a gank, allowing Vizi to take a strong hold of top lane so Shaco can farm bottom lane mid-late game.
What's sad, the three threads within the last three days all have something in common: 0 Shaco games.  "NERF CHAMP CUZ REASONS".

Shaco basically only dominates the early game, and that's because of his ability to snowball lanes early or destroying the enemy jungler.  He falls of mid game, and falls off harder in late game due to poor team fighting presence.  He is by no means OP.  This is just one of countless examples of clueless bandwagoners misjudging a champion's full capabilities because "omG I SAWS ON LCS, CONFIRMED 5EVER"

Shaco is infuriating to play against because his early ganks, potential for cheese, and ability to invade are so high.

I would say most of the people saying he's OP probably got cheesed and lost because Shaco was 4-0 in 8 minutes.  He's really good for getting your lanes ahead but he falls off harder than most assassins when the teamfighting starts... 

I always laugh when I'm against a shaco because I know all I have to do is passively farm my lane and in 25 minutes we can win the 4v5.

Im guessing we've never crossed path :P

Shaco has amazing split push ability late game, rather strong dueler thanks to his clone. With good box placements, it's rather simple for him to escape too. 

If Shaco gets fed, he can easily instagib squishy carries before team fight even happens. 

Passively farm your lane could definitely stop a shaco from snowballing, but that is only if your team do the same and/or give up dragons :)

I watched that game, I mained Shaco for some time to Plat 1 and have been demoted while I was trying to main Heimer, going back to Shaco now though.

Shaco had very little impact in the early game.  He power farmed to mobility boots.  The announcers even commented about how he was low and hadn't gone back, he didn't gank either.  What caused Shaco to be able to dominate the split push and almost 1 shot EZ is that his lanes won on their own for the most part.  He got top snowballing, but after that he just farmed up split pushing and didn't have kill participation until after they were on the inhibs.

What that game showed, just like with any other champ, is that if the team as a whole is doing good then you will too.  If GMB was winning bot lane, Shaco would have been ganking them while they were pushed up and GMB could have counter-ganked him which is a real weakness of Shaco.  However, all lanes were losing for GMB so Shaco could safely and easily split push without having to worry about his team getting destroyed in the 4v5.
Lately in games whenever there's a Shaco on my team the enemy puts a vision ward on their side of the river. It completely counters Shaco.

I have a feeling it is also in combination with the sudden exposure most of the community got to Shaco via URF. Regardless of whether he is OP or not, People see him in URF, and then shortly after see him in pro play. In URF, Shaco is absurdly strong. In that pro game, Shaco got just the right scenario and took a team that was already going on tilt and drove them nuts, continuing to snowball the game very easily. Either way, Shaco ends up *looking* REALLY strong in those two situations, and people who don't have the wherewithal to think about the surrounding circumstances (i.e. Shaco is an aggravating and uncommon pick to play against, so UOL took advantage of the fact that GMB was starting to go on tilt from the last 2 matches in combination with the fact that Diamond undoubtedly wasn't extremely comfortable playing into a Shaco because of Shaco's rarity and suddenly Shaco becomes doubly effective) don't realize that outside of those circumstances, Shaco will do just as well as he always has.

A good shaco is hell to play against... but he isn't broken because how hard he falls of in teamfights (though he is pretty good at split pushing because of how slippery he is and because he is a pretty good duelist with his fear + the possibility to doge abilities with his ult and or blocking them with his box and his clone deals 50% of his AD so it deals pretty good damage and well his pretty strong burst with IE + Decieve crit + backstab damage increase) 
But Shaco is also very hard to play correctly and a bad shaco isn't much to worry about after all if he doesn't snowball himself or his team he loses a lot of his power and potential which is less likely to happen is shaco isn't good
Precisely, Shaco is and has been very balanced for a while now, as a niche pick champion who excels in a certain comp and team style (which is why UOL pulled it off so beautifully).
